The construction of Machu Picchu and other Inca structures is a testament to the advanced engineering and stonework skills of the Inca people. They had a unique construction technique that involved carefully fitting together large stones without using mortar. This technique, called ashlar masonry, allowed them to create strong and durable structures that have withstood centuries of earthquakes and weathering.

The Inca civilization also had a sophisticated road and communications network that allowed them to transport materials and communicate over long distances. They used llamas as pack animals to transport heavy loads, and the network of paved roads allowed for efficient transportation. This, along with their advanced knowledge of agriculture and hydraulic engineering, allowed the Inca civilization to thrive and grow.

It's also worth noting that the Inca people had a strong communal culture that prioritized cooperation and sharing of resources, which likely contributed to their ability to undertake such massive construction projects.
